SEARCH
Module org.klojang.db
Package org.klojang.db

Class SQL

java.lang.Object
org.klojang.db.SQL
public class SQL extends Object
A factory for SQLQuery, SQLInsert and SQLUpdate instances. An SQL instance represents a single SQL statement that cannot be changed. The {statement can be parametrized in two ways:

  1. Using named parameters for values in WHERE, HAVING and LIMIT clauses. Named parameters start with a colon. For example: :firstName. Named parameters are not bound in the SQL instance itself, but in the SQLQuery, SQLInsert or SQLUpdate instance obtained from it.
  2. Using Klojang template variables for the other parts of a query. Although this basically lets you parametrize whatever makes you happy, it is especially meant to parametrize the sort column in the ORDER BY cluase - a common use case in web applications. Klojang template variables must be set in the SQL instance itself.

In other words, the SQL fed into an instance of this class might look like this: 


 SELECT *
   FROM EMPLOYEE
  WHERE FIRST_NAME = :firstName
    AND LAST_NAME = :lastName
  ORDER BY ~%sortColumn%

You would then set the age and salary variables in the SQL instance, request a SQLQuery from it, and then bind the firstName and lastName parameters in the SQLQuery instance: 


 SQL sql = SQL.create(theAboveSQL);
 sql.set("sortColumn", "BIRTH_DATE");
 SQLQuery query = sql.prepareQuery(conn);
 List<Employee> employees =
 query
  .bind("firstName", "John")
  .bind("lastName", "Smith")
  .getBeanifier(Employee.class)
  .beanifyAll();

If the SQL statement contains many named parameters and Klojang template variables, and is going to be executed often, you might want to cache the SQL instance (e.g. as a static final variable in your DAO class).

Author:
Ayco Holleman

    • setSortColumn

      public SQL setSortColumn(Object sortColumn)
      If you decide to go along and parametrize the sort column using a variable named ~%sortColumn%, this method lets you set the value for that variable.
      Parameters:
      sortColumn - The column on which to sort
      Returns:
      This SQL instance

    • setSortOrder

      public SQL setSortOrder(Object sortOrder)
      If you decide to go along and parametrize the sort order using a variable named ~%sortOrder%, this method lets you set the value for that variable. Calling toString() on the argument must yield "ASC", "DESC" or an empty string. The argument may also be a Boolean with false being translated into "ASC" and true into "DESC".
      Parameters:
      sortOrder - The sort order
      Returns:
      This SQL instance

    • setDescending

      public SQL setDescending(boolean isDescending)
      Sets the value of the ~%sortOrder% variable to "DESC" if the argument equals true and to "ASC" if the argument equals false. This presumes (and requires) that you have that variable in the SQL statement.
      Parameters:
      isDescending - Whether to sort in descending order
      Returns:
      This SQL instance

    • setOrderBy

      public SQL setOrderBy(Object sortColumn, Object sortOrder)
      Sets the values of the values of the ~%sortColumn% and ~%sortOrder% variables. This presumes (and requires) that you have those variables in the SQL statement.
      Parameters:
      sortColumn - The column on which to sort
      sortOrder - The sort order
      Returns:
      This SQL instance

      public SQLQuery prepareQuery(Connection con)
      Produces a SQLQuery instance from the SQL passed in through one of the create methods. Calling this method for SQL that is not a SELECT statement has undefined consequences.
      Parameters:
      con - The database connection to use when executing the statement
